Bye Bye Joe Hockey goodbye The former Treasurer has resigned. Denis Carnahan and Rocco Fazzari reflect on budgets past. With apologies to Don McLean (and Madonna).
PT1M7S 620 349 Independent senator Nick Xenophon wants the rules governing politicians' entitlements tightened to prevent former MPs who take up diplomatic postings from being able to simultaneously access their parliamentary superannuation.
Senator Xenophon said on Sunday that former treasurer Joe Hockey should not claim his parliamentary pension if he is appointed Australia's ambassador to Washington D.C., a move that is widely expected.
"I just want to help Joe Hockey achieve his dream of ending the age of entitlement," Senator Xenophon said in a reference to a speech Mr Hockey gave in London in 2012 when he called for the welfare system to be wound back.
Former treasurer Joe Hockey delivers his valedictory at Parliament House in Canberra on October 21. Photo: Andrew Meares
Mr Hockey gave his final speech to Parliament on last Thursday in which he called on politicians to strike a bipartisan deal to end free education and healthcare for the well off.
Advertisement Mr Hockey will officially bow out of political life later this year with a byelection for his seat of North Sydney scheduled for December 5.
If Mr Hockey were to be appointed ambassador he could choose to claim a portion of his parliamentary pension in addition to his ambassador's salary.
Independent senator Nick Xenophon says millions of dollars in unnecessary legal costs are being incurred by taxpayers. Photo: Christopher Pearce
Federal MPs lose 50 cents in the dollar from their Â­annual parliamentary super incomes if they hold a diplomatic post with the Commonwealth government.
Senator Xenophon, a long time critic of the system of political entitlements, said MPs should not be able to access to their parliamentary superannuation if they were appointed to a diplomatic post.
"This looks a lot like a double dip by ex-politicians. It is beyond community standards. It is not reasonable," Senator Xenophon said.
Former South Australian premier Mike Rann was discovered in 2014 to be earning nearly half a million a year because he was earning his salary as the then high commissioner to Britain as well as being paid superannuation from his state political career.
He was forced to take a pay cut after Senator Xenophon drew the matter to the federal government's attention.
Senator Xenophon said he would travel to the United States early next year to look at the automotive industry but he would cover the cost of the travel himself.
"I can do things on the cheap ... I know all the Greyhound bus schedules," Senator Xenophon said.
